Same series, both series 1, both high print runs. We'll see if one of the boxes is better than the other. We can definitely tell you the blaster boxes this year way worse. Now the jumbos, are they that much worse? They did make a little tweak and they did make them a bit worse. They took out a relic. There's one relic and one auto per box. Used to be one auto and two relics. So, we're down a a hit, but that's the only difference. Let's see and compare these boxes. Thank you very much for joining us. It looks like those are due in tomorrow to the PO box. text:
BLASTERS ARE BAD THIS YEAR?! INCREASED PRICES, LITTLE YIELD. 

Hey everybody, welcome back to another brand new release preview video. Today we're taking a look at the last boxes. We already covered the jumbo boxes and the hobby boxes and they were pretty good. Can't say that there's much of a anything to talk about negatively about them except the fact that the jumbo boxes got rid of one of your hits. Hobby box have been great. Now we're looking at blasters and I'm not so sure before I even rip any of these how I feel about these blasters. First of all, they went up in price. You don't realize it, but they went up in price. Let's talk about how. Boxes from 2025, they were $25 a piece. Boxes from 2026 are also $25 a piece. Except the big difference here is used to get 84 cards in last year's blaster boxes. Now you only get 72. So, they have taken a pack out. A complete pack is gone. Instead of seven packs per box at 12 cards each, you now get six. So, what does that mean for your price? Well, I do the math. Last year, you got 84 cards at $24.99. That's 29.75 cents a card. This year, the price is still the same for the box, but at 72 cards, you're paying 34.7 cents per card, which is the equivalent of paying the price of $29.15 per box. All you do is take that 34.7, multiply it by 84 cards, and that's what you know, that's what the price increase is is gone to. So, basically, it it's almost like buying the S last year's box for 29 bucks. So, big price increase on these blasters by $4 to $5. And are they going to be worth it? Well, I don't know. We'll go ahead and check it out right now because you've seen these out at Walmart. You've seen them at Target. You've seen them out there. And you might wonder, should I spend some money on this? Should I maybe buy like, I don't know, four blasters, or should I go buy a hobby box? Let's find out. We're going to open up 10 of these blasters in this video. We're going to start with this one right here. This is for Keith. Good luck, Keith. I've been opening a lot of series 1, especially in our whatnot breaks. Hope you can check those out. I'm going to open up tomorrow's breaks and put those on sale here this afternoon very shortly. So, Keith, good luck to you. Unfortunately, one less pack now in 2026. That's just the way things are going. You can see Stars of MLB are going to be back, although they're not in every pack anymore. So you don't have to deal with that every single pack, which is good. I don't know of anybody that liked Stars of LB, was a serious collector last year. Half the cards are going to be those Titans of the game, and the other half are going to be Stars of LB. I like that. I That's a step in the right direction. All right, let's see what we do here. I would like them eventually to maybe make six different little insert sets if that's what they're set on. Maybe just one one of them per pack per box. There's a Kuna on the 91 stars of them will be on the Simei Bayio. There's your design. Basio's a good rookie. It's had a long-term deal with the Orioles
title: BLASTERS ARE BAD THIS YEAR?! INCREASED PRICES, LITTLE YIELD.

text:
Dealers PANIC After Sudden PSA Price Hike!

After an absolutely crushing month of submissions in January, PSA raised prices with no notice to dealers, which sent them and collectors scrambling for answers. What should you do next? We'll tell you now. Hello sports card investors and welcome to another episode of cards on the table. Teapot Haley, we got we got some price hikes to talk about today. We got some things happening in the crazy stats coming out of the world of grading. We also have a really wonderful collector story, a great collector story. I'm excited to tell the audience about that. We're gonna get to that in a minute, but let's start with this PSA news. You guys want to jump in there? Let's do it. >> Are you ready? >> It's the topic of the week for sure. >> Oh yeah. >> This this right off the bat, this really caught my attention. So Ryan Hogue, the president of PSA, head of graders for collectors, >> president of grading. Yeah. >> He goes on Neo Cards and Comics, he says that in the month of January, PSA took in 150,000 cards a day on average as their submission volume. They were processing and shipping back out 90,000 cards a day on average. >> That is a big delta. By the way, that 150,000 cards per day, the most ever. But we're putting a graph up on the screen just to show people like the submission volume, how high the submission volume was in January, last month, compared to all other months. You can see it just going off the charts and their ability for them to keep up with it. They can't keep up with it. It's they keep hiring more people. PSA's capacity, if you go back to 2021, was 15,000 cards per day. That's what they could handle in 2021. Now they can handle 90,000 cards per day. So they have increased their capacity by what is that? Six times >> over the course of the last five years, but the submission volume is has has increased at a way greater rate. 150,000 cards a day in January. Absolutely incredible. So the only way that PSA knows how to slow this down right now so their team can keep up and this backlog doesn't become 6 months, nine months, a year like it was during COVID is to raise prices. And that's what PSA did. And PSA did that on Tuesday of this week without notice to anybody. And the price increases were somewhat significant, especially if you are into Pokemon and TCG. they got affected the most because if you were part if you submitted cards previously under TCG bulk submissions it was $18.99 a card. Now it's up to $24.99 a card for those bulk submissions for collector's club members. Sports bulk went from $21.99 a card to $24.99 per card as well. What they've done is they've combined TCG and sports into one category called value bulk. That's now $24.99. And then a lot of their other service levels, value, value plus, value max, regular, they all went up $5 per card. So, it may not sound like a lot on an individual card basis, but I mean, if you're doing an order of 20, 30, 50, 100 cards, >> right? >> It starts to add up really quick, right? Um, they
title: Dealers PANIC After Sudden PSA Price Hike!

This is a sealed box of 1981 Tops football. And if I get lucky, there is a $60,000 Joe Montana rookie card sitting inside this box. We're going back in history. We're going back to 1981 Tops Football, 36 packs, and we're expecting 15 cards per pack. So, 540 cards coming out of this box. Most likely, we will get one of every card. Now, that doesn't mean we actually will get one of every card. Math would suggest we should get one of every card, but chances are we'll probably get two or three of certain ones and zero of other cards. It just kind of depends on how the coalition ended up here. Like, there's a lot of like just kind of 70s, you know. OH, THERE WE GO. That's what I'm talking about, ladies and gentlemen. We hit the Joe Montana rookie card. We got nice looking corners, edges. We've got no surface stains or issues. We are not super well centered, unfortunately. You can see there's a little bit of a shift on the front, the left to right centering. There's slightly more white bar on the left than on the right, but on the top and the bottom, it is even more evident. There's more white bar on the top than the bottom. So, that is unfortunately not well centered enough to get a PSA 10 or probably even a PSA 9. And I think you're probably looking in like PSA 8 territory
title: Looking for a $60K Joe Montana Rookie in 1981 Topps ðŸ”¥

text:
Trading Over $428,000 In Cards on Veriswap!

I did more than $20,000 in trades on VeraSwap last month, but did I get them wrong? Did my VeraSwap trade partners get the best of me? We're going to debate that, plus some other huge [music] trades on VeraSwap now. [music] Hello sports card investors and welcome to another trade [music] talk with VeraSwap. Teapot. The Veris Swap platform has been absolutely on fire this last month with tons and tons of trades all the way from sub $100 trades all the way up to trades involving cards that are worth tens of thousands of dollars and more. And we're about to dive right in and debate some of the biggest. You ready for this today? >> These are actually my favorite trades so far that we've covered. So, I'm pumped. >> This is a really good spread, including this first one. Let's bring this one up up on the screen to start. We have a Michael Jordan, the classic 1986 Fleer rookie in a BGS95 being traded for a 2019 Prism Kobe Bryant gold number to 10 in a PSA 9 and $14,000 in cash teapot. This is truly a huge trade. What side do you like? I cannot believe how hot Prism Gold cards have gotten over the last few years. It's I don't know if it's absurdity. I I can't wrap my head around you. talking about one of the most iconic cards of all time. Some say the most iconic card in the Jordan rookie and a 2019 Prism Gold Kobe, but you get the cash, but you're talking about almost like a $30,000 valuation on this Kobe based on what those MJs go for. That's mind-blowing to me. I did say a few years ago in a market movers video, I think probably three or four years ago when we were looking at the panini era stuff that I thought among the things that would carry value forward, I thought gold prisms in particular were a strong candidate as well as kabooms and some other things and those have kind of but I didn't expect this level of insanity for this card. And if you're talking about rookie cards, you could go get a PSA 9 Topps chrome refrator of Kobe for the same price as they're valuing this PSA 9 gold prism. You could also get a PSA 10 of a card I know you and I both love, which is that finest airs gold refractor in a PSA 10. There's only 28 of those. >> Or this. >> Yeah, I'd rather have that. >> I'd rather have that. So in this case, like while I love Prism Golds, while I love Kobe, I love $14,000 in cash. I go with the Jordan in this. Even though I know there's a lot of them, I I still got to go with the Jordan. >> I'm glad, Tapot, that we can once again disagree right off the bat. I feel like the last couple of shows we've been too friendly with each other. We agreed on we agreed on too much. I don't agree. I don't agree at all. >> Do you think there's upside? >> I think that I that the Jordan, the 86 Fleer Jordan, there's so many of them out there. And I agree that it is the iconic, you know, Jordan rookie. Well, that and the 84 star, but the 86 Fleer is so many of them out there. And yes, 95 is a great grade on it, no doubt. But the Kobe, I believe that is his l
title: Trading Over $428,000 In Cards on Veriswap!

text:
Sports Card Investing & Collecting for Beginners (2026) Everything You Need to Know!

It's the 2026 edition of sports card investing and collecting for beginners. If you're new to the sports card hobby or simply want to sharpen your skills, then this video is for you. Today, I'm going to give you all of the basics you need to know to become a successful sports card investor and collector. Hello sports card investors and collectors and welcome to sports card investing and collecting for beginners. I'm very excited to do this video with you today because sports cards have been my life for the last several years and I absolutely love cards and I absolutely love teaching what I have learned along the way including some hard lessons. And I'm going to be giving some of that to you today to get you started on your own journey. If you don't know me, my name is Jeff Wilson. I'm the founder of this YouTube channel, Sports Card Investor, also the founder of Market Movers, which we'll talk about later in the video. It is an app that helps you track the price of cards and track your collection. And also the founder of Cards HQ, this big card shop behind me here in Atlanta, Georgia, and hopefully more locations of this card shop opening across the nation soon. And between Cards HQ and myself personally, I have bought and sold more than $100 million in sports cards over the last several years. So, I've got a lot of experience, not all good experience, some bad experience, a lot of great lessons to share your way, which we're going to be doing today. We're going to be covering the best sets, the best products, the brands, the manufacturers, how to buy and sell cards, how to find good deals, how to grade cards, the best cards for investment opportunities, and so much more. [snorts] So, let's jump in. The first thing I want to talk about today are the eras of sports cards. We're going to start with a little history lesson because it sets an important foundation for you investing or collecting in sports cards. Most of the video we're going to talk about today will be around ultramodern cars. Ultraodern is considered the era from 2017 through present. And most of the video is going to focus on that because chances are if you're newer getting into sports cards, most of the cards you're seeing, buying, selling, most of those are likely from the ultramodern era. In fact, they're probably from the last year or two. And if you come into a card shop like Cards HQ, a lot of the cards you're going to see on display, and most of the boxes that you might buy to open, they're probably all recent releases, meaning those releases are from the last several months. So all of those cards are going to be from this ultraodderern era. But before we start talking about cards in the present, let's go back to the past and let's talk about vintage cards. Vintage covers all cards that were manufactured prior to 1980. And in fact, vintage goes all the way back to the prewar era, where you'll find, for example, the 1909 T206 Hanis Wagner card, considered by many to be the hol
title: Sports Card Investing & Collecting for Beginners (2026) Everything You Need to Know!

text:
Patrick Mahomes Cards Selling for $12K A PACK? ðŸ˜±

Would you pay $12,000 for one pack of Patrick Mahomes cards? Well, Panini thinks you will as they are releasing 2025 Panini authentically Mahomes and it's listed at $12,000 on Blowout. That 12K gets you one pack with eight cards. Those eight cards include two oncard autos, one other auto, plus gem and memorabilia cards. Now, these are Patrick Mahome's first Panini autographs since 2020, so that's a big deal. But $12,000 when Mahomes is injured and the Chiefs are bad, that seems to me like a tough sell. What do you think? How will the market respond to this? Let me know in the comments.
title: Patrick Mahomes Cards Selling for $12K A PACK? ðŸ˜±
